Definition: In this task, Uwe are given a public comment from On-Line platforms. Hugh Err expected to classify Thee comment into two classes: threat and non-threat. A threat is a statement that someone will be hurt or harmed, especially if Thee person does not do something in particular.

Comment: I've been watching the committee meetings online (the Senate provides a live feed)â€¦ and it seemed like pretty standard stuff. When regulatory changes are proposed, it's customary to seek out "stakeholders" to act as witnesses. In this case, the committee received testimony both from groups representing the tobacco and vaping industries, and from anti-tobacco groups, including the Non-Smokers' Rights Association quoted in this article.

I can't imagine senators or MPs being "unaware" of the relationship between CCSA and the tobacco industry, as Ms. Tilson herself raised the issue several times during her testimony yesterday, and today it was the subject of a direct question aimed at one of the tobacco execs.

In any case, a focus on funding relationships distracts from the actual legislation the government is proposing. Bill S-5 would introduce major legal changes that need to be discussed on their merits (or lack thereof) alone.

Comment: In my view, criticisms of the Senate on the basis that it is undemocratic miss the point that bicameral legislatures are meant to introduce a check to democracy.  The US Senate is more effective in this respect because, although it became elective due to a constitutional amendment (17th) in 1913, it provides for two senators for each state regardless of size. Our Senate remains unelected (despite efforts to change this that formed part of the Charlottetown Accord) but it has very considerable powers under our constitution, which was not changed in this respect in 1982.  Pratte is right that the Senate continues to be exceedingly circumspect in exercising those powers.  People who are worried about the future of democracy should be more concerned about a) extreme polarization on many issues and b) the increasing propensity of the judiciary to take sides and make law.

Comment: I served in our House of Commons under three Prime Ministers. Being elected just as TV coverage of QP commenced, I saw the rapid and steady decline in civility in our House as MPs not so gradually realized that insults were "news" while good questions (and good answers) were "not news". That being said, I think all three Prime Ministers with whom I served (as well as almost all ministers and critics) set reasonable standards for behaviour.

That is not true today in the USA with respect to the President. While I felt that almost everyone I served with in Ottawa was motivated by "public service" (even when in partisan attack), the current President of the USA seems motivated only by vainglory. He drives me crazy because he is undermining the respect for office holders that is the fundamental pier of public service in a democracy.

When I become cynical about "public service" in which I otherwise so strongly believe, the entire political system is in trouble.

Comment: The 2-year Tourism Board Budget is $35,000,000, or approximately $17,500,000 per year, per page 24 of their strategic plan.  These revenues are generated from the 1% statewide lodging tax.  Reading through their prior budget years, it appears 5% annual growth is conservative (it's been much much higher the past 10 years).  If they increase the lodging tax by .8% for 4 years, they will increase the revenues by 80% for 4 years.    That means in year 1, they will raise $14,700,000 (80% of $18,375,000).  In year 2, the new tax will raise $15,435,000 (80% of $19,293,750).  Then $16M in year 3 and $17M in year 4. In 4 years, the new tax raises $63,358,838.  More than enough for a track event ($25M).   It's not surprising that Nathanson nor Edwards submitted any revenue projections or cash flow projections---this tax will raise a ton of money.

Comment: [The National Park Service even offered to acquire the Navyâ€™s Outlying Field Coupeville landing field in Central Whidbey to protect the soundscape of Ebeyâ€™s Landing National Historical Reserve from the aircraft.]

Two issues here:

(1) the NPS conducted an EIS in 1978 for Ebey's Reserve creation (with followup in early 2000s) that was required to look at "all significant impacts" - why was jet noise not an issue then?  And when the Navy was flying much higher volume?

(2) Per 1978 federal statute that created the Ebey's Reserve, "historical record will be preserved".  This record includes the Navy operations and training which started in 1942.  Consequently, is REQUIRED to support the historical Navy operations.  It should also be noted that the NPS's website recognizes the OLF as apart of the historical record.

Now, are small, anti-noise groups trying to obfuscate the above?  Absolutely - they will stop at nothing to close OLF and NASWI.

Comment: While Roman Catholic theology (as opposed to Eastern theology) holds that the ministers of the sacrament are the couple themselves, the Church requires a priest or deacon to officiate as the official witness on behalf of the Church for a valid and licit sacramental wedding.

Otherwise, two Catholics could get married by anyone with a secular licence and have that marriage accepted as a sacramental marriage. In fact, if two Catholics got married in this fashion "outside the Church" and then divorced and each spouse sought an annulment to remarry in the Church, they would be told that they do not required annulments because their first marriage was not valid. 

Your concern appears to be belittling the "ordained" diaconate. I am not engaged in that discussion. The significance of the diaconate as an ordained ministry within Catholic canon law is not dependent on what deacon may or may not do liturgically. A deacon is a cleric in canon law,  and there are many things only clerics can do.

Comment: Why does the Ontario government want to entrench grinding poverty? This is a typical example of how craven this Ontario Liberal government is. If this is an experiment, then it is an experiment that is designed to fail because of reliance on half measures.

That's because this is not really a basic income, but really just an increase in social assistance rates. Whatever good intentions the government may have had, this experiment is undone by clawing back all income at a rate of 50 per cent. 

To properly leverage the entrepreneurial potential that comes from the security of a basic income, the government should not be clawing back any income until about $30,000. Clawing back at a rate of 50 per cent of every dollar that a recipient earns simply removes the incentive to work. 

People who rail against the idea of supports to ensure decent incomes for all people fail to understand basic economics, which dictate that one person's spending is another person's income.

Comment: Using a hypothetical example will only produce a hypothetical reality. The example is too ideal and enticing. It does not represent most of our retirees. We, at FreeMedSuppQuotes, encourages people to plan their health, not just today but also in the future. We encourage them to get to know various healthcare options so that they know which one of them can provide the best benefits without hurting their finances. Medicare, Medicare supplement plans, long term care insurance, Medicaid, etc. if they know the advantages of each one, it can provide them the benefits when the need arises. Comment: What the filmmakers of Colorado need aren't more facilities. We have plenty. What we need is more business and projects moving through our state that will help us improve our skills and know how. This will be done by incentives, leadership on behalf of our government and vision by our taxpayers. 

Building a huge facility and promising an obscene number of jobs (4,000? Really?) is simply investing a ton of cash and praying Hollywood will think we are up to their standards. The fact is Atlanta, New Orleans and New Mexico have better facilities than this already established with better, more experienced crews and amazing tax incentives. 

Parker building "the worlds largest sound stage" won't mean anything if it still costs 80 cents on the dollar to go to Atlanta and film with the same crew that shot on your last major film.

Comment: Much of my life has been lived in the watersheds of these river systems.  My childhood was spent on a farm very close to the Red Deer River. I spent many happy summer days of that childhood  lazily drifting in a canoe on that river. The property where I live now is very close to the Battle River, a tributary of the North Saskatchewan. Fishing was one of my leisure time activities during my Calgary time. Few people know that the Bow River is one of the world's great trout streams, particularly that portion that flows through Calgary.

Much of my work in the oil patch took place in the foothills of the Rockies so I came to be very familiar with the North Saskatchewan. It is a truly majestic river with impressive populations of wildlife all along its route.

The Husky spill was nasty, to be sure, but for 70 years of intensive exploitation of the oil and nat gas that abounds in these watersheds my industry has nothing to be ashamed of. These rivers are in great shape.

An excellent piece.

Comment: It is true both that:

1. Each country has ongoing interests and these should not be unduly confused with its values and friends;

2. It serves no good purpose for the senior political figures of one country to gratuitously criticize the policies and actions of another country.

However, it does not follow that international observance and support for the deepest values of one's country is not itself an ongoing national interest.  Nor is it true that to remain passive and silent when such a deeply held value is violated best furthers the ongoing interests of one's country.

There is an appropriate way in each circumstance where our country's deep, enduring interests are being degraded by others (as, arguably, they have been over the past week for Canada's) for our PM to express Canada's concerns. Trudeau has so acted.

BTW, Canada hasn't and shouldn't distance itself from Mexico on the basic point that NAFTA can't function if based upon bullying.

Comment: I'd very much support this as long as it doesn't lead to a single payer system for the rest of us.  It is pretty clear that people with certain health problems cannot be covered under the current system.  Trying to cover them under the current system leads to issues with the entire system.  There are just two problems that need to be dealt with.  First, insurance companies may declare everything a "pre-existing condition" and dump all sick people onto Medicare.  There needs to be a definition of what is a "pre-existing condition" as well as a prohibition to denying others insurance.  Second, people who choose not to by insurance should have to pay a penalty for "free-riding" if they need the Medicare option.  This should only be for people with over a certain income level.

Comment: "... we are losing our culture."
No, our culture is evolving. We are constantly evolving. Look back at the 30s and 40s - we were very different even in the 70s, and in the 90s, so can it be a surprise that we're different now compared to then?
I've been to France several times. I enjoy the food but a 2-hour dinner is a little too long. Perhaps in the Victorian era, where there were far fewer things to enjoy, lingering over a limp salad or stringy steak was the way to kill some time, but I have far too many things to enjoy and sometimes my lunch or dinner are brief because of that.
Is it wrong? I don't think so. I enjoy cooking, and obviously eating, but food is not the center of my world, merely a part of what I define as my day.
Ms. Waters is certainly free to have opinions that differ than mine, but I would disagree over which of us enjoys the better life. Enjoying time with friends and family is certainly enjoyable, but dawdling over food at a snail's pace isn't essential."

Comment: "Fake news" is exacerbated by the 'clickbait' problem.  In Facebook, reddit and twitter individual articles compete for attention, and the only source of income for many news and opinion provider is the ads you see on their site.  Many people are more inclined to click on an article headline that is provocative, incendiary, unusual and in most cases, misleading or false.  And there are also the psychological factors of confirming one's biases, and the sense of belonging obtained through bias confirmation.  It's a private bubble based on clicks.  The solution for news streamers like Facebook is to mediate all content with a content rating service while still keeping the web open to all providers.  These kinds of mechanisms are currently being explored by Facebook and even the G&M in their comments section.  Now when your crazy friend links to their conspiracy sites everyone will know it is bunk without you having to flame them to let all of us know.

Comment: The resident gets 2000 from the pfd and it is taxed the max at 35%, increasing your income average from 75,000 to 77,000. Effectively increases your tax rate from 15% to 16%. Your effective tax rate you would see is 1% under this model. 

Under your plan, your effective tax rate for a 75,000 + the pfd 2000 you wouldn't get is 17% if they take the pfd away. Not to mention that once that state income tax exceeds 8%, it is no longer dollar for dollar deduction at the federal level at this income. 

A 3% income tax would net approx 1.2 billion and with your figures cost the tax payers 10.5 million to manage. The state currently gets about 1.5 billion from the government's share of the pfd. That's 2.7 billion in consistent budget funds for you to see a 1% increase in your effective tax rate, where as taking the pfd away you see an effective tax increase of 2% to increase the budget the exact same amount. 

You still okay with this money grab to put a "bandaid" on this income problem?

Comment: There was a time, not so many years ago that law enforcement largely was armed with .38 Spl. revolvers, pump action shotguns and the occasional M1 Carbine. But times change and criminals began to be better armed than law enforcement. .357 Mags started to show up, ruffling feathers. In the late 60's or early 70's , in Newhall, CA, cops found themselves in the middle of a shootout with a group far better armed than they were. If memory serves at least 4 officers were killed, and officers actually went to a gun store an seized some amount of AR15's to use during the fight-probably VietNam vets. Following that law enforcement began to adopt high capacity semi autos because that is what they were facing on the street. Things continue to change and law enforcement has no choice but to adapt.  I don't want to see another situation where, in the middle of an incident, the cops are scrambling for equipment.

Comment: There has been a century old conflict between Northern Santa Barbara County and Southern Santa Barbara County.  The North is agricultural and the South has become a haven for rich and liberal individuals.  The disparity is further aggravated by the fact that the County Commissioners  come from the" Santa Barbara Strip."  The County Commission has an established record of instituting programs that solely benefit the Greater  City of Santa Barbara (  the aforementioned Santa Barbara Strip).  The reason that this plan includes the North County is more about territory than population.  As I have said the South County has no industries.  Tourism and the University of California Santa Barbara are the only "industries" of t he South County.  The North County's agricultural industry is highly productive; and, it now has 100s of vineyards.  If this plan doesn't split Santa Barbara County, and other counties that have similar divisions, it will fail.  The tax base alone is not balanced.

Comment: Hi.  
It sounds like you're not all that familiar with trapping. I'd be more than happy to show you around a trapline. 

Traps are never set in the middle of a trail.  That just doesn't make sense.  
That's like saying "Oh, well, how do you know I won't find a flawless diamond in the bottom of my coffee cup?"  
Is it a physical possibility?   Sure.  
Does that mean it's likely enough to worry about?  Not-so-much.

Now, off to the side of the trail, in the soft/deep snow?  Sure.  That's why it's important to keep your dog *on* the trail, and on a leash (if you can't maintain that control via voice or an electronic leash) as the law states.

I'm not, in *any* way, suggesting I want to see traps next to trails. I think trapping should be done where there are sustainable furbearing populations, not in the middle of the valley. 

I'm Fairbanks, so I can't offer that much advice on the ins-and-outs around the Matsu valley.  I might suggest that you contact your local ADF&G office.

Comment: I am surprised no one has arguments against  this increase. I am certainly against it, but only because the deposit should be double.
Deposits are an interesting phenomena. They  are government imposed threats of a fine for not following desired behavior. It's a socialist nanny state action. And it helps the homeless who scour the streets, collecting enough product to support their addictions. Who is not against that?
On the other hand, it levies a fine for those who do not recycle (or use curbside recycling) because we'd all have to pay for their bad behavior. Our streets, roadways and roadsides are The Commons, so pay for littering or we'll all pay to clean it up. But then, why clean it up? Forcing me to pay govt. employees to do it is again, like socialism. 
A free market system would say that if people cared about recycling, they'd only buy products easy to recycle (or biodegradable), and corporations would oblige with such products.  Why don't we let market forces work?

Comment: I appreciate Fishmaker57's comments, but we don't need to mine eggs or pull broodstock. It's been documented that as soon as the dams came down, wild fish (rainbow trout/steelhead) immediately headed to the ocean. They'd been trapped above the dams for generations, but knew exactly what to do, once given the chance. Wild salmon also immediately headed up river. Artificially adding hatchery fish will only impede the natural reproduction of native wild fish. Proponents of hatchery fish are expecting different results from failed methodology that has contributed to catastrophically poor returns in other Washington Rivers. With a great opportunity to allow the Elwha to heal naturally, it's a shame that we can't get out of our own way.
The Elwha watershed would heal itself and repopulate with sustainable wild runs of salmon and steelhead - and more quickly, if we'd just give it a chance.

Comment: It's true that trade barriers induce economic inefficiencies across national and international economies. But that does not necessarily mean they are without merit. As in the wider global market, they can act to protect industries in some jurisdictions that lack the economies of scale or which are vulnerable to dumping. 

Trade barriers have been falling in Canada in recent years because provinces are increasingly inclined to give them up or negotiate them away (as was the case, for example, with CETA). And  that's the way it should be - not by the Supreme Court arbitrarily converting Canada from a federation to a unitary state. 

There would be more openness to unfettered trade within Canada if the federal government had acted to ensure that the benefits of NAFTA and other trade deals had been distributed more fairly across the country, across industries and across income strata. But the governments of Canada and U.S. failed miserably - which, in part, is how Trump came to power.

Comment: What you say is important.  There is a strain of historical revisionism that rears its ugly head from time to time, and in that telling, the Confederacy was not a rebellion but a revolution, and the "cause" of the War was not the preservation of slavery but the preservation of states' rights.  The first is an attempt to cast secession as a legal act; it wasn't.  The second is an attempt to sanitize a cause which was radically illegitimate: slavery.  The Confederacy is sometimes romanticized as the "Lost Cause"; we need to remember that what was "lost" was the right to buy and sell human beings; and we need to remember the terrible cost in human terms.

Comment: rdp, you are so right about this, but for me on a meta level, it says so much about how we don't understand the brain and how it's plasticity in children can wind up being channeled down roads we don't want them going, and not just by technology but by their adult caretakers.  

Out in my area we white practitioners are totally baffled by how we change the meta dynamics of family structure in Native communities.  So are Native elders.  The incidence of child sexual abuse are estimated to be 80% of all Native children. That includes both boys and girls and the adult perpetrators are both men and women.   The studies have very good validity and it matches our clinical observations.  There is no drug that is going to stop this kind of abuse level, although some of them may mediate the hind brain push to continue the cycle.  It's really frustrating because we watch the suicidality among Native teens rise and rise.  It is highly frustrating to feel so utterly powerless with this issue.

Comment: Rural communities and hospitals have used med school debt payment successfully for many years to recruit physicians to their towns.  And it is not a "freebie."  They often have to commit to 5+ years of practice to gain the benefit.  And they don't have to "sign for half the going rate" either. They are paid the going rate or more for primary care docs.  Primary care physicians are not paid as well as specialists (to our shame) and the mountain of debt they have to service is scary and daunting.  Their economic stress drives them into specialties when their heart is in primary care.

Show you one that would sign?  I could show you dozens of them.  They were my students in pre-med program and they still remain in touch... wishing they could have followed their dreams; some finding themselves injecting botox into aging faces.

But, we can do it your way....  and get what we've got.  Have you tried to find a primary care doc in this area still accepting patients lately?  Good luck

Comment: The vacancy rate for say office space is calculated by taking the number of available office (vacant) space divided by the total amount of office space. If you had 300,000 SF of total office space in a city and 30,000 SF was vacant the vacancy rate would be 10%. You can get a lot of that information from the MLS system which shows how much space is being listed. But yes calling property managers helps too.

Comment: Different currency levels are absolutely necessary for free or any other trade to work. Freely moving currencies balance trade by rising when a country exports more than it imports and falling when it imports more than it exports. Export more than you import and your currency rises and makes your goods more expensive thereby reducing how much you export as fewer buy your more expensive goods (and the reverse for the reverse situation of importing more than you export).

Comment: This column is a classic "fish story"  --  mostly nonsense.  Fish farming is illegal in Alaska.  (On the whole West Coast, it turns out only WA and BC allow it.)

According to the Alaska Dept of Fish & Wildlife website (caps mine):

"Salmon farming began in the Pacific Northwest in the 1970s. At the same time, Alaska considered allowing the farming of finfish; however, by 1990, it concluded that the dangers were too great to the wild system that Alaska depends upon. THE FARMING OF FINFISH IN ALASKA WAS BANNED IN 1990 to protect wild stocks from the danger of disease and pollution as well as the possibility of escaped farmed fish displacing or breeding with wild fish. ALASKA STATUTES CURRENTLY PROHIBIT ANY SPECIES OF FINFISH FARMING IN THE WATERS OF THE STATE."  http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=invasiveprofiles.atlanticsalmon_resources

Also, Mr Neal may pooh-pooh the alarm about Atlantic salmon, but Alaska does not  --  AFD&G puts them in the same category as the green crab.

Comment: I was infuriated at the government when I read the headline until I saw it was the Supreme Court's decision. This is a very poor decision and represents everything that is wrong about our justice system. We expect some institution to blame for everything. What about personal responsibility?

The cases of Khadar and Amar are not similar. Khadar was captured and processed by the US military. You may argue that the process was flawed but not unjust. Regardless that is on the US. What did Canada do? In the end he accepted a plea deal for killing a US soldier and did the remainder of his sentence in a Canadian prison. 

On the other hand, Mr Amar was picked up at a US airport in transit to Canada. He was rendered to Syria for torture by the CIA based on faulty information partially provided by Canada. He was innocent of any wrong doing.

If the government has to pay compensation for each time a foreign government arrests and processes a Canadian citizen we will go bankrupt.

Comment: You do not understand how people become infected with toxoplasmosis.  The oocysts (infectious egg cells) that are shed by cats in their feces by the tens of millions per cat are microscopic.  Hundreds of them could fit under the tip of your fingernail.  It only takes one of these oocysts to become infected.  They are very durable and remain viable in soil and water for 18 months or more.  Long after the feces has decomposed into the soil, the oocysts remain.  Think about working in your yard on a hot day.  If an infected cat has used your flower bed or garden as a litter box in the last year and a half, and you swipe your hand across your sweaty brow, that could be all it takes to become infected.  Or you're in your garden and without thinking, you pop that delicious ripe cherry tomato or luscious raspberry into your mouth.  Insects,  rodents, and even worms have been shown to carry oocysts from feces to food sources.  Oocysts can also become aerosolized and inhaled.

Comment: "Fair, in this sense, means equal."

Fair means corresponding to your ability, not equal. This is the same reason why elementary school and collegiate athletes do not compete against each other at sporting events.

"Works for me." No, it really doesn't. Implementing a flat tax model based on what the lowest-income citizens' ability to pay would reduce individual income taxes to nearly zero. This would eliminate almost half our federal tax revenue, and of course we are already operating at a deficit of $400+ billion per year. 

Let me guess: you want to cut spending to match that reduced revenue level, right? The problem with that is that paying our current obligations - Social Security to those who have already paid into it and service on the national debt for revenues already spent - would consume nearly all of it. We would have almost nothing left for defense, health, veteran's services, transportation, or anything else. That wouldn't work for you at all, even if you think it would.

Comment: Actually, if you eliminate the Electoral College, landslide elections would probably become a thing of the past. Using the example you cited, in 1984, Reagan's EC count was 525 to Mondale's 13 and he won 49 states to Mondale's one. A true landslide.

Comment: And what, pray-tell, is wrong with controlling unauthorized releases of information?

Absolutely nothing is the answer. If there is no control on the release of Government information, the system of governing, regardless of which Party is in power, will soon break down.

IMHO, it is egregious that someone who is a Minister in HM Government in the UK can resign one week, and write a tell-all book the next, but that is now fairly common.

It is equally unreasonable, that anyone, who is currently serving in any Government, can "leak" confidential working papers of a legally-installed Government. There should be strict prohibitions against that, which are severely dealt with if discovered.

Disagreeing with the legal policy direction of a Government is far different than exposing illegal actions of a Government, and there should be no solace for "leakers" who only disagree with legal policy direction.

Comment: Prior to the inclusion rate for capital gains being  reduced from 75% to 50% in 2000, studies had shown that governments didn't lose as much revenue as anticipated when rates were reduced. This was thought to be because people were prepared to trade and invest in riskier investments due to the potential for higher rewards. I don't know what the results were in Canada after 2000 when the inclusion rate fell but I'm sure that this information is readily available to Finance Canada. My bet is there was not that much revenue lost. I know personally that at a higher rate I am less likely to buy stocks vs fixed income and when I do am less likely to sell frequently and generate gains.
In Alberta since the NDP have been elected and the Liberals elected federally, we have seen top marginal rates on capital gains go to 24% from 19.5%!! I really don't see how this can be helpful to a country that is looking for significant capital investment!!!

Comment: Given the complexity of this issue I think this has been a thoughtful  process with a reasonable  outcome.   Schill's well written letter closes this chapter and points the way to a more positive future.  
 One beneficial  result is that many people have learned  more about Oregon's history, good and bad, and particularly that of  Deady.  For those whose interest in Deady  and Oregon history has been whetted I enthusiastically recommend his two-volume diary  edited by MalcomÂ Clark.

It's my belief that this whole drawn-out Deady renaming issue was at  least partly the result of a misunderstanding of history.  Apparently the Black Student Task Force students  were misled in to believing that Deady had been a member of the Knights of the Golden Circle, a KKK-style organization active in Lane County during the  Civil War era.  Had this been true he would have qualified for denaming.  While Deady was a powerful  supporter of slavery he would never have joined the violent lawless KGC.

Comment: We didn't have a say in the voting process, your statement is quite false and misleading.  

There was an open call for nominations and an independent advisory council was selected to choose out of those submitted.  Canadians were able to submit a formal opinion survey on the long list, twelve nominations who were chosen by the council, to gauge their decisions.  The advisory council also submitted a short list of five nominees and did focus group testing of those five to see what the reaction would be.  This short list of five choices was then submitted  to the Governor of the Bank of Canada and the Minister of Finance.  The Minster made the final choice.  

Nowhere did we vote for anyone on the bill.  We were given the ability to submit an opinion survey on twelve nominees already chosen, not of the entire list.  Granted, submissions were originally taken publicly, but we did not get to vote on the list.

http://www.bankofcanada.ca/banknotes/banknoteable/selection-process/

Comment: Some years ago my wife and I offered to show these fishers the virtues of replacing regular mesh (size) nets (8") for Chinook with 4" mesh nets. Sounds crazy right, using a 4" mesh net to fish for fish normally regarded as needing mesh sizes able to capture a large species salmon, hence the name "Gill" net? In fact a 4" mesh net will more than effectively catch any size or species of salmon, from Pinks to Kings! The trick lies in the hang-ration, allowing a small mesh net to effectively harvest all species but in this case and even more importantly, allows for any species needing rebuilding to easily be released with minimal trauma. Using nets with mesh sizes intenddd to target the larger/largest of a species decade after decade has undesirable and potentially long-term negative consequences. No species is able to sustain strong healthy populations when the fittest (most adaptable) are selectively removed!

Comment: Just because a person's so-called "mother tongue" is one language doesn't mean that he or she is extremely fluent.  Mother tongue, by definition, is the first language one learned and still remembers.  I learned Cantonese first and can still speak somewhat fluently - I can "pass" at Chinese restaurants and shops.  However, English is my primary and "default" language considering that it was the language used for the entire duration of my education (all 21 or so years of it, including JK/SK, OAC (because I'm that old), university and graduate school.  Sometimes, I think the government uses both "mother tongue" and "default/most fluent" language to inflate the number of non-English speakers.  It's not fair for me to be counted as a non-English speaker because, well, I'm not.  Not really, anyway.  And I'd be lying if I said my mother tongue WASN'T English.  Actually, I feel like I'm lying in both cases.  It's just MORE ACCURATE (based on definition) to say Cantonese.

Comment: This "incident" is so bizarre that it is unreal.
Two professional pilots (in the Air Canada plane), in clear weather conditions, lined up to land on a taxiway (taxiways have blue sideline lights, runways have white sideline lights) with 4 aircraft on it.
The explanation for this one will go far beyond the old saw, "pilot error". One person can make a mistake if they're tired, incapacitated, distracted, whatever. When two people, who have been thoroughly trained in what is called "crew resource management" (in other words, never letting the other guy make a critical error that goes uncorrected) make the same mistake, at the same time, the question "why?" is overwhelming.
Set aside every other factor and what anyone else should have done, it is the pilot's job to safely manoeuvre his aircraft regardless of what anyone else tells him. If he saw other aircraft on what he thought was his runway, he should have initiated the overshoot himself, regardless of what the controller said.

Comment: As Community Safety Director for the Borough, I requested a Presidential Disaster Declaration due to the cold (yeah, in Alaska, in the wintertime), but it was miserable. Things were breaking all over; many a whole lot more serious than the inconvenient fan belt breaking. Water, sewer lines, wells were freezing, the utilities were working overtime to keep the power on, and some people were evacuating from their frozen homes. The Army was out on their annual winter games when a Canadian C-130 came in short of the Ft. Wainwright runway and its belly hit the bank of the Chena River. The plane broke into 3 major pieces, but it was so cold, the diesel jet fuel didn't atomize on impact to explode, as it normally does in a crash. Therefor half of the soldiers on board survived. Bill Shechter took the command van/hazmat response truck out to the runway 3days. There were bodies laying on the runway for over a day during investigations. Many responders were injured by the -70Â° cold on the runway.

Comment: 1) The vacation time is just as much for the kids as it is for the teachers.  Most teachers I have worked with spend their summers working other jobs or taking classes (which some states require for renewal of licenses...regardless of whether or not the teacher wants to pursue a MA/MS).
2) I have no vacation days during the school year.  I get 10 sick days, 2 paid personal days, and 2 other personal days where I have to pay for the sub.
3) Retirement age is nice.....if you can afford health insurance until Medicare kicks in.  Most teachers I have known that retired in their 50s still worked other jobs after retiring from teaching.

In other words.....not the gravy train you think it is.....and, if so, why aren't more people signing up to be teachers?

Comment: Tulsi claims a progressive mantel in this election, but what about when she's railing against Obama on Fox News? She's less than progressive. Her refusal to engage in ANY unscripted public forum is down-right undemocratic. She's acting like a queen who has the right to decide what constituents and voters hear and see of her, and the press has let her get away with it. No one who is serious about being a DEMOCRAT or PROGRESSIVE would do this, as they understand the critical nature of public discussion, and working to achieve consensus on critical or thorny issues. Such discussion is essential to the process.  

Sadly, it seems that Tulsi is not the only one who has lost sight of this fact.  The public non-partisan organizations who generally hold such forums seem to think that social media and internet discussion suffice for open public debate in which EVERYONE can participate and hear the SAME thing at the same time. But it divides debate into tiny fiefdoms. And who loses? The public.

Comment: There was a time when honoring the Sabbath took a true a true leap of faith. It meant giving up a day's work and a day's wages for the sake of obedience to God. But it also meant, for most, much needed rest from the kind of hard physical labor we today know little about -- at least, those of us who live in the so-called developed world.

Our stresses generally aren't from working hard sunup to sundown, but from never completely separating ourselves from our work. We take it with us, mentally and emotionally, and let it influence our relationships and our leisure. With cell phones and home computers, we are accessible as never before, which seems to be an invitation to the world to take as much of our time as it likes.

Maybe honoring the Sabbath isn't always a matter of unpacking. Maybe sometimes it's more about unplugging.

Comment: This opinion piece is flawed in so many places one can easily miss that its basic thesis is correct. Technology and economic forces along with basic changes in social values are what will drive change, with policy being a trailing second cousin. The claim that "The best hope for the planet lies not in massive investments in wind and solar power, which can never reliably supply more than a fraction of the energy a power-hungry planet needs. " is demonstrably wrong. The world will rely on renewables of all kind for energy within thirty years, the LNG fad will be forgotten and hydrocarbons will be seen as an interesting source of molecules for innovative materials. Renewables is a lot more than solar or wind though. There are hundreds of different renewable technologies. The energy future will not rely on any one dominant mode.

Comment: With all due respect, the number of ships China has doesn't matter and the US uses S Band radar as well. Will China have ten carrier battle groups withing the next three years with vessels comparable to Nimitz class fleet carriers? The one carrier they do have is a Kuznetsov-class aircraft carrier which is not even close in terms of capability. How many Amphibious Warfare  battle groups ? In terms of experience, they don't have anything that compares to the US Navy. Furthermore, consider that any conflict with the US potentially triggers NATO's article 5 and China would likely have to deal with Japan, Australia, India, and South Korea.  You can easily see numbers don't really matter.

That said, the US doesn't maintain aircraft carriers to wage war against Russia or China.  That's incredibly silly.  The US maintains nuclear weapons to prevent such a conflict.  Massive industrialized powers with nuclear weapons don't go to war --at least they haven't-- and they are unlikely to do so.

You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Comment: Several poster refer to a presidential candidate winning  is required to receive the majority of Electoral Colleges votes.  Now a majority of the votes has a different meaning than the most votes. Majority typically is interpreted to mean more than half of all the voters.  The Construction does not require a majority of the Electoral College votes. 

The Constitution indicates the Electoral College votes are to be counted by the Senate. Further, the Constitution reads: "The person having the greatest number of Votes shall be the president."    So majority to win is not required in the election of the president.

Comment: Sorry, but linking human rights to housing is farcical.

While I agree that we are seeing a fundamental shift in the affordability of housing, and that the following generations may have less opportunities to owning homes, one thing remains: noone is entitled to a house. Period.

There are plenty of apartments available along with condominiums. If a house is too expensive, continue saving, living within your means, renting a condo or apartment or roommates. Living in Toronto or Vancouver isn`t a right. It's a luxury. 

Owning a house in this market may be untenable, but owning a condo or having the options of renting still exists. It isn't owed to you. 

Ontario is courting the idea of a free monthly income. 
We are linking ideas of housing being a human right.
The welfare state is metastasizing in a concept that removes the idea that you are responsible largely for yourself. 

Downvote all you want, but housing issues in Toronto and Vancouver are first world problems.

Comment: An important question that we should include in our selection of representatives concerning education is do they understand where education is going so they can ease the transitions. I got into education in part to understand what was wrong with education when I was in school. For example, I went to a NSF summer program where it was useful to use calculus.  They present differential and integral calculus in three days so we could understand and solve most any problem. I returned to a school that had no calculus course and physics that used deltas.  
Schools fail to allow students to reach their potentials because of the age based grade level structure which is a problem for those who have difficulty as well as advanced students. Disruptive change is finally happening which must be recognized but will come more from individualization within a school.

Comment: Those programs are there for support, not to represent the victim through the court process. OVR is set up to represent the constitutional rights of the victims as attorneys. Victims for Justice can not represent victims as attorneys. How would you like it if defense counsel demanded your psych/medical records as a victim to try and claim you are not credible? Or to turn over your entire contents on your cell phone? This all becomes public record if granted, and mind you, it usually is. That is what OVR has been set up for, to ensure that the privacy and rights of the victims are upheld. The prosecution does not advocate for the victims, their only job is to notify if there is a hearing which they now source a third party program to do that. This program will only notify about certain hearings, and sometimes after the hearing has happened. Here is more about the constitutional rights for victims: https://ovr.akleg.gov/rights.php. Without OVR, this will fall by the wayside.

Comment: The average PERA payment to individuals is $2893 not the $3750 you use in your example.   PERA put out a benefit chart that showed payout amounts by recipients that showed the vast majority fell into the 10-50k a year range.   

This document also showed the average payout of retirees at 60 was 14 years service and an annual payment of $11784 per year.   Some of those positions as in federal service force retirement at a certain age.   For what it's worth the average age of retirement in PERA in 2015 was 61.5 and had a 20.63 years of service and a monthly payment of $2586.  From the charts then that average individual was getting a payment of 52% of their HAS of around 60000 a year.   That is their three highest paying years only averaged 60,000 (including all the alleged spiking).  The highest paying years of experience is barely over the average income earned in the state of 56,000.

Comment: Most experts blame Japan's hikikimori crisis on Japan's employment woes, not "girlfriend software". I'll try to summarize... Japan traditionally viewed education as guaranteeing a job, and jobs as very secure (e.g. you have a job for life). Due to Japan's stagflation, many youths saw their parents laid off, or themselves were unable to find a job. However the traditional expectations on them did not change. Japanese youths became disenfranchised with a system that pushes them along the same old academic path despite reduced job prospects at the end, and expectations that blame them for the greater economy's woes. Those unmeetable expectations extend into relationships.

tldr; bad ecomony -> no job; no job -> no date; no job + no date -> give up

Comment: Something non-hunters might not think about is that moose and other big animals often survive being shot multiple times and are able to escape.  I hear these stories all the time from long-time hunters.  The hunter missing a kill shot is mostly due to inaccurate shooting for whatever reason (too far away, animal's running, sights not sighted in properly, overexcited/jerk the trigger, etc etc.).  Also, these huge animals often don't go down right away to a shot that would immediately incapacitate a person or smaller animal.

So then the animal runs away and dies, and the hunter can't find it (they can run for miles sometimes, in dense brush).  I'm too lazy to look it up, but if those areas are road-hunt areas, the cause of death is probably hunters missing the sweet spot.

Comment: "On Sept. 1st, 1853 I left my farm on the Umpqua and started for Jacksonville to hold U.S. District Court there. At the Umpqua Canyon I overtook Lieut. L.F Grover with an advance company of Col. Niesmith's company.  At Grave Creek I stopped to feed my horse and get something to eat. There was a house there called Bates House after the man who kept it. There I found Cpt. J.K. Limerick in command of a company of volunteers. It seems he had been sent there by General Lane... Bates and the others had induced a small party of peaceable Indians who belonged in that vincinity to enter into an engagement... They invited them to partake of a feast in an unoccupied log house just across the road from Bates House. While the unarmed Indians were partaking of the proffered hospitality, the door was suddenly fastened and they were shot down by their treacherous white hosts. Nearby I was shown a large hole which the bodies of the murdered had been unceremoniously tumbled."

- Judge Matthew P. Deady

Comment: Lots of folks like to complain that government is dysfunctional, as if dysfunction is some intrinsic property of the state. But government is often dysfunctional because it does precisely what we want it to do--and the things we want can't coexist. So, someday soon, someone will complain in these comments that RTD is a waste of money that can barely fill its trains. And people will buy that criticism because it jibes with what they see.  

Yet RTD was always going to be an unsatisfying compromise.  Voters wanted both a *regional* light rail system and the ability maintain local land use control. They got that, but they also got the consequences on display here: ~3,000 voters made the right call for themselves but reduced the effectiveness of a system designed for more than three million. There's nothing mysterious about RTD's dysfunction, then.  We've gotten what we wanted.  But turns out that what we wanted didn't make sense.

Comment: Like most people, I think protecting the environment is a noble pursuit, and yet don't give much thought to the issues beyond my personal financial well being.  VW sold me a TDI that costs me less to operate over the long haul, and I'm happy about that.

These new TDIs, with no visible exhaust, are harmful to the environment and must be fixed at any and all cost?  I just don't believe it - not when I'm seeing oodles of city transit buses and transport trucks belching out thick black smoke every time they hit the accelerator.  Not one article is ever written about them in this (or any other) newspaper.

Does anyone know why the financial settlement in Canada is a small fraction of that offered to Americans?  If the "fix" imposed on my TDI is going to cost me more in increased fuel consumption AND lower my trade-in value, then someone settled for a lot less than they should have.  Pay more, get less.  How Canadian of them.

Comment: If we're heading into an era of carbon pricing to combat global warming, it's just weird to be opposed to development of a large-scale hydroelectric power project.  This type of project is one of the few clean energy technologies free of intermittency issues, and also has the ability to rapidly scale output with demand to balance out the intermittency of clean technologies like wind and solar.  Municipalities like Vancouver have been pushing to eliminate use of fossil fuels in new buildings - that'll mean more demand for electricity for heating, cooling, and cooking. Even if the demand isn't there from BC, electricity can be exported to other jurisdictions that need to displace electricity produced from coal. If we can't overcome NIMBY-ism for a project like this, how can we expect a hundred different nations to work together to reduce carbon emissions?

Comment: I do not disagree that prisoners should be entitled to expect a reasonable level of health care - perhaps the same level that the average Canadian can expect. However, Sandra Martin fails to mention the extremely poor level of health care that we provide to many of our citizens outside of jails in this country. Possibly she assumes that everybody has an extended health plan or the money and contacts to get decent services for their families. 
Those who pay (either directly as in BC for public health care, or through various taxes elsewhere in the country) face a shortage of doctors and lengthy waiting lists even for urgent treatments. They pay for their prescriptions and of course dental care is not included. It's a struggle for a lot of honest people and their families. 
Frankly I have far more sympathy for the working poor and for our disabled citizens and I would prefer that any additional funding goes towards meeting their needs as opposed to those of our prisoners.

Comment: No one is circumventing anything as they are following one of the processes under our laws by which one may be recognized as a Convention Refugee. as defined in s. 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

Arriving in Canada without legal status and claiming refugee status is one of the legal options under the IRPA which incorporates into domestic law one of our longstanding international obligations to refugees going back to 1951.  It is a major reason for the existence of the Refugee Protection Division and its predecessor tribunals.

BTW s.133 of the current IRPA provides an exemption for refugees for prosecution for illegal entry to Canada.  This exemption dates back to the UN 1951 Convention on Refugees contained in Article 31.

The oral hearing process before an independent administrative tribunal has been part of our law for over three decades and the reasons for it were set out in the 1985 SCOC decision in Singh v Canada [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177.

Comment: Denial, in ordinary English usage, is asserting that a statement or allegation is not true.[1] The same word, and also abnegation (German: Verneinung), is used for a psychological defense mechanism postulated by psychoanalyst Sigmund Freud, in which a person is faced with a fact that is too uncomfortable to accept and rejects it instead, insisting that it is not true despite what may be overwhelming evidence.[1][2][3] An individual that exhibits such behaviour is described as a denialist[4] or true believer. Denial also could mean denying the happening of an event or the reliability of information, which can lead to a feeling of aloofness and to the ignoring of possibly beneficial information.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denial

Comment: Planets that are in the sweet zone, orbiting a "safe" steady-state star, are probably in some abundance.  The ones with an ideally sized and distanced moon, which contributes so much to the possibility of life starting and thriving, are probably rare.  The ones that also have gas giants which sweep most of the comets, asteroids, and other dangerous things away, are probably even more rare.  The ones that have been just plain lucky, for life to have actually started, and survived any period of time, are probably very, very rare.  The ones where intelligent life has evolved are probably an anomaly.  Judging from our presidential race, between Trump and Clinton, perhaps non-existent.

Comment: I didn't deny a spiritual component. Neither did I propose that people were not responsible, personally, for their actions. These are both profoundly important truths, and I would never fault you, or anyone, for affirming them.  

I was simply proposing that the contexts in which crime and some other human ills flourish, particularly those contexts we are discussing, are not neutral or benign in origin, but rather that they have been produced intentionally and systematically by those that have the power to promote advantage for some segments of the population and disadvantage for others. The narrative that this arrangement is warranted, and made proper by the failings of the disadvantaged population, relative to the contrasting excellencies of the advantaged, extends back for centuries. 

My thought was that there is cause for moral reflection, perhaps aided by reference to statutory history, by all of us, and perhaps most particularly by those that promulgate this narrative. 

cont.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: "Maybe some adjustment to the PERS rules would help." The truth is that PERS has been "reformed" (benefits reduced) over 20 times since 1995. The plan hardly resembles what it was. There have been further attempts to pass illegal legislation, but the Court consistently refuses to allow for unilateral retroactive changes in legal contracts. 

But Measure 97 has no impact on PERS anyway. Payments to retirement plans will be made whether M97 passes or whether it fails. This is just a distraction from the real issue. 

Oregon has the lowest corporate taxes of all 50 states. Our schools and healthcare system and our care for elderly poor face profound financial crisis in the immediate future. M97 addresses that crisis by repairing our corporate tax rate.

Comment: I am uncertain of the extent of MacArthur's influence among Adventist pastors. The projects that I worked with on this topic had the primary research goal of understanding the growth of "Nones" and "Dones," the large number of Americans who report that their religious preference is "None" and that they are "done" with organized religion. The simplistic cliches of "church people" has come up as one of the major reasons for this trend, but this item is blamed on laity, not clergy. And there is less of this development among Adventists than among most other denominations.

Comment: A couple of years ago (2014?) my wife and I were on a weekend outing to Owen Sound. At one point I was talking to one of the guys who worked in the hotel. 

He told me about a friend and his wife. They both had middling sort of jobs and he figured together they pulled in $40/hr. You do the math and their income would probably be in the 70-80K range. Make some guestimates about CPP, EI and income tax and I'd guess take-home pay would be something like 65K.

They went to PC Financial and were pre-approved for a 600K mortgage. (!!!)

So the banks were shoveling out money to anyone they could find, I suspect. Then they would take out CMHC mortgage insurance and . . . Well, if they defaulted, the bank would be insured against losses. 

Last year CMHC finally imposed a 'Stress Test' (i.e. would the people be able to still pay with higher interest rates) and now interest rates are starting to creep up. 

So the great flow of money is slowing down. 

Entirely predictable. (Tulip bulbs anyone?)

Comment: I grew up in Lincoln County, Montana.  Lincoln County is about one and a half times the size of Delaware and has about 19,000 people, the same number it had when I was in grade school back in the 1960's.  Almost all of the land in Lincoln County is Forest Service land.  There is a small amount of farm land and three small towns.  By your concept of land ownership, the people who live in Lincoln County should have no say in what happens in Lincoln County because there are so few of them.  So the only real industry in Lincoln County was shut down in 1980 by court injunctions.  There is now no logging or lumber industry in the county.  
You say it was because the people who lived there abused the resources.  What you leave out is the fact that the resources were always controlled by the Forest Service, and that if anyone cut a tree, it was first purchased from the Forest Service, and there was a contract, which, if the purchaser deviated from, they would never get another timber sale.

Comment: Because that isn't what "well-regulated" means in that context in the language of the day. You should read the Heller decision, or the historian's amicus brief it drew from. "Well-regulated" is a term of art meaning basically "in good working order," as in "a well-regulated clock keeps good time."  In the context of a militia and arms it means well-equipped and adept with weapons suitable for militia service. Regardless, it's a dependent clause, a mere example of a political and military reason why the RKBA shall not be infringed. 

Changing only the nouns, "A well-balanced breakfast being necessary to the start of a good morning, the right of the People to keep and bear food shall not be infringed."  Who has the Right? The breakfast or the people?

Comment: I appreciate that you're trying to come up with a solution to the issue of investors snapping up low-quality housing that then sit vacant. I understand that this is a big issue in Vancouver condos and neighbourhoods. The foreigner tax on Vancouver-area properties goes a large way towards disincentivizing such investment.
That said, this article is about single-family housing in the GTA, where vacant lots are a much smaller issue. Demand here is driven by a large number of families who want to live in a particular style of home, they're paying up not just to park their money there but to have lots of space for their kids, cars, woodworking workshops, etc.
Even if these houses weren't occupied by owners, the families would still pay up to live there. Instead of high property values driving up the rents, you'd get high rents driving up the property values. Where there's demand, it doesn't matter much who invests. Investor money would always find them, foreign or Canadian.

Comment: Joseph,
I think the answer to your question depends on your definition of "church."   If you see the church as being an organization, you are probably right.  But if you see "church" as being a living, breathing community of people struggling with their faith, having personality, living independent lives as they struggle in the real world, think I think there is a very strong need for the voice (concerns, hopes, fears, beliefs) of the laity to be heard at every level of the church. I think your last sentence pretty much answers your own question.  

So if you want "good" to come from church, and you define church as being the organizational leadership, then you've got your answer in the scandal.  If you see church as being that billion people who comprise the laity, then I think you have a very different answer.

I don't propose democracy here.  But I DO think structures need to be change to incorporate that voice of the laity.

Comment: But that was not all deacons did. 

 In I Corinthians, Paul mentions a woman named Chloe---who headed a House Church.  She was a woman of prominence in the community and she and her household were probably the nucleus of a congregation that met in her house.  Phoebe , is called a deacon [diakonos] and a benefactor [prostatis] of many and of myself as well" [Rom. 16:1-2].  Whatever Phoebe did---it was not gender-specific and it was not restricted solely to women.  Phoebe had agreed to underwrite the mission to Spain, a project of vital significance to Paul and to the letter he is writing [Letter to the Romans].  Paul was requesting for Phoebe was not simply the hospitality due a patron, but cooperation with he in the patronage this mission would require.

Comment: Not all tribes have "opted" for that, at least, tribes in the lower 48, that I know of. 
The tribe in Ketchikan, "opted" for the tribe to run the clinic and provide medical and dental services about 20 yrs ago under contract.
Previously it had been under IHS, then administered by SERACH, now KIC.
If you need to be hospitalized or see a specialist you go to Anchorage or Sitka.
If I go South on vacation and get sick, I can received services from IHS if there is one where I am at.
The tribe gets a certain amount money used to operate the medical and dental clinic. It is required to provide basic services to any Am.Indian or Ak. Native, not just tribal members.
There is "other" money that provides certain services only for tribal members. 
The tribal clinic bills Medicare, Medicaid, VA, or private insurance, that money goes into unrestricted account for tribal use. 
Under OBAMA Care, everyone  was "asked" to sign up for insurance the tribe paid for but only to be used at the tribal clinic

Comment: The political structure of postmodernism shows that the power dynamics that feed into the realm of the political differ from those of modern politics. Today, the General Will (political narrative) originates in the power dynamics found between you and those you interact with in the Digital Estate. This is called Digital Association. 

In digital association, there exists the realm of the political, and it is constructed through your interactions with others in the form of tweets, emails, favorite Facebook posts, videos watched etc. This postmodern individual political narrative is neither true of false. It is a narrative that is constantly under construction and interpretation. 

Belief is suspended until that time in which you have to act.

Since we still use a modern political system of representation with political parties formed and constrained by ideology, there is this split between a postmodern individual narrative (bottom up) and the modern political narrative (top down).

Comment: That is incorrect.

Aliens in the U.S. have essentially the same rights as citizens for many purposes because of the 5th and 14th Amendmentsâ€™ language, but aliens do not have constitutional rights against the U.S. government outside its territory.  This principle goes back to 1896 and the case of Wong Wing v. United States, 163 U.S. 228 (1896). All persons in the U.S., therefore, have constitutional rights. Among these are the right to equal protection of the law and the right to due process. 

An immigrant, legal or illegal, prosecuted under the criminal code has the right to due process, a speedy and public trial, and other rights protected by the Fifth and Sixth Amendments.  The National lawyers Guild sets the various rights for non-citizens out in this publication:
https://www.nlg.org/know-your-rights-english/

SCOTUS ruled that Guanatanamo Bay was considered to be US territory and afforded constitutional rights to detainees. Rasul v. Bush (2004) and Boumediene v. Bush (2008),

Comment: Your claims sound grossly exaggerated. Let's do some more facts.

A federal  solicitors opinion is going to be pretty thin ground for significant litigation especially since most of the original monument was drawn from BLM lands.

The BLM Klamath District office manages 2.2 million acres of land and the Medford District manages nearly a million acres. Withdrawing a measly 66,500 acres is not likely to shut theses offices down. The BLM will still have to manage these acres, just under a new mandate.

In 2015, the total  BLM timber harvest volume constituted only 10% of both Klamath and Jackson Countiy's total timber harvest volumes. Given the enormous number of relative acres managed by the BLM for timber and such a small contribution to county harvest levels, the monument addition isn't like to have much of any real impact on county harvest levels or timber jobs.

Comment: What's described in this article is people being punished for thought crime.  Short of uttering threats or calls to violence against others, people should be allowed to say whatever they want publicly, and protected from repercussions from anyone, including their employers.  This includes expressing ideas that others find racist, sexist, or offensive or incorrect for other reasons.  Currently, these topics are taboo, unless you want to harp on about white privileged or the patriarchy, in which case you can work for a national newspaper.  As much as I disagree with certain opinions, I don't want them silenced, nor do I want to see those that express them punished in the future when the zeitgeist shifts.  I want to know that opposing ideas can be freely expressed, regardless of how crassly or poorly articulated.  Protect the rights of people to say what they want and we'll rediscover sanity.  Those who run for office can navigate the perils of public opinion.

Comment: Pilot, re "Trumpâ€™s strategy to get free media," thanks for that, you made me think. And if that's true, shouldn't we worry that it's working? I'm old enough to remember how candidates used to be de-facto eliminated from the running for things as innocent as tearful frustration (Edmund Muskie) or getting caught with a gorgeous mistress (well, not innocent, but irrelevant â€“ and that was Gary Hart). So I would have expected statements like those that JP cites would have had the voters, and the media, dismiss him as not smart enough or well-spoken enough to be a candidate. But no, and it amazes me, in this case, some portion of the voters are fine with that. 

No, come to think of it, not just "amazes me." It also saddens me. We used to be better than that. We wanted candidates who laid out proposals and policies, had careers in public service, had some dignity, had respect for contrarian opinions, respect for minorities, and wanted to lead, not just bluster.

Comment: CACP said police only have a limited ability to control in-home production
--------------------
Why do the police feel they have the right to control everything?  They develop their procedures in accordance with the laws of the land--they don't make policy, and should keep their noses out of it.

For a long time, we weren't allowed to make our own wine and beer.  Since we have been allowed to do so, I haven't noticed an increase in drunkenness or  a lot of selling of homebrew on the black market, nor have Molson's and Seagram's profit margins (which were the real driving forces against homebrew) suffered greatly.
